results.title: Aspirin Use to Prevent 1st Heart Attack or Stroke Should Be Curtailed, U.S. Panel Says
results.abstract: Adults at high risk for cardiovascular disease may face serious side effects if they start a daily regimen of low-dose aspirin.
org_facet: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality
United States Preventive Services Task Force

media.caption: Doctors would be discouraged from starting patients on a daily dose of baby aspirin to prevent heart attack or stroke under proposed new guidelines.

results.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger and Brenda Wintrode
results.title: U.S. Navy Engineer Charged in Attempt to Sell Nuclear Submarine Secrets
results.abstract: Jonathan Toebbe and his wife tried several times to pass information on nuclear propulsion systems to a foreign government, according to a criminal complaint.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: A Virginia-class attack submarine in Hawaii last month. Nuclear propulsion technology used in U.S. submarines is highly sought after.

results.byline: By Ken Belson and Katherine Rosman
results.title: Raiders Coach Resigns After Homophobic and Misogynistic Emails
results.abstract: In emails detailed by The New York Times, Raiders Coach Jon Gruden casually used misogynistic and homophobic language to disparage people.

media.caption: In a postgame news conference Sunday, Raiders Coach Jon Gruden addressed an email in which he used a racist trope to describe DeMaurice Smith, the head of the N.F.L. Players Association.

results.adx_keywords: Actors and Actresses;Breast Cancer;Chemotherapy;Television;Doherty, Shannen;Instagram Inc
results.title: In Candid Photos, Shannen Doherty Shows the Ravages of Breast Cancer
results.abstract: The actress, 50, who has Stage 4 cancer, said she posted the photos to help raise awareness about breast cancer prevention.

media.caption: Shannen Doherty, center, in blue, with the cast of “Beverly Hills, 90210,” in 1991.

results.adx_keywords: Vaccination and Immunization;Malaria;Preventive Medicine;Parasites;Disease Rates;Deaths (Fatalities);Children and Childhood;your-feed-science;GlaxoSmithKline PLC;World Health Organization;Africa
results.title: A ‘Historic Event’: First Malaria Vaccine Approved by W.H.O.
results.abstract: Malaria kills about 500,000 people each year, about half of them children in Africa. The new vaccine isn’t perfect, but it will help turn the tide, experts said.

results.adx_keywords: Comic Books and Strips;Superman (Fictional Character);Homosexuality and Bisexuality;United States Politics and Government;audio-neutral-informative;Taylor, Tom (2001- );DC Comics;Comics Code Authority
results.title: Superman Comes Out, as DC Comics Ushers In a New Man of Steel
results.abstract: The new Superman, the son of Clark Kent and Lois Lane, is concerned about the environment, does not shy away from politics and will soon begin a romantic relationship with a male friend.

media.caption: Jonathan Kent, the new Superman, who is the son of Clark Kent and Lois Lane, shares an unexpected kiss with his friend Jay.

results.title: Researchers find a higher than expected risk of myocarditis in young men after full vaccination.
results.abstract: But the risk remained rare, and the condition temporary, the team found.

media.caption: Adam Osman, 17, receives his first dose of the Pfizer-BioNtech vaccine at ACCESS, an Arab American social services organization in Dearborn, Mich., in April.
media.copyright: Emily Rose Bennett for The New York Times

results.title: The Best Places to Have Babies
results.abstract: A new study compares health care costs, accessibility to care, and baby- and family-friendliness in the 50 states and Washington, D.C.

results.adx_keywords: United States Economy;National Debt (US);Social Security (US);Federal Budget (US);United States Politics and Government;Treasury Department;Senate
results.title: What the Debt Ceiling Means for Social Security and More
results.abstract: The Treasury secretary says the government will run out of money to spend if Congress doesn’t raise the debt ceiling. Here’s what that could mean for programs that help millions of Americans.

media.caption: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen during a Senate committee hearing last week.
media.copyright: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times

results.title: They Had the Vaccines and a Plan to Reopen. Instead They Got Cold Feet.
results.abstract: Singapore’s experience offers lessons for other countries that want to reduce pandemic restrictions but have yet to deal with widespread infections.

media.caption: Walking outside in Singapore, where an early response to the pandemic helped keep infections low.
media.copyright: Ore Huiying for The New York Times

results.title: Bolshoi Performer Is Killed in Onstage Accident
results.abstract: The man, in his late 30s, was crushed during a scene change as the opera “Sadko” was performed before an audience, the theater said.

media.caption: A performer was killed onstage at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow on Saturday during a performance of Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov’s “Sadko.”
media.copyright: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Forensic Science;DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid);Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Bentaas, Theresa R;Sioux Falls (SD)
results.title: 40-Year-Old Cold Case of South Dakota Baby Ends With Conviction
results.abstract: Decades after a baby was found by the road, DNA testing led to criminal charges. On Friday, a woman entered an Alford plea in the case, accepting a guilty plea for manslaughter without admitting to the crime.

media.caption: Theresa Bentaas walking in the Minnehaha Courthouse in Sioux Falls, S.D., in 2019. Prosecutors dismissed murder charges against Ms. Bentaas, who entered an Alford plea in the case.
media.copyright: Briana Sanchez/Argus Leader, USA Today Network

results.title: If You’ve Had Covid, Do You Need the Vaccine?
results.abstract: So-called natural immunity varies from patient to patient, scientists say. Immunization is still the best choice after recovering from the disease.

media.caption: A Covid patient in isolation at the University of Arkansas in Little Rock, Ark., in August.

results.abstract: Home health care workers must now be vaccinated in New York State.

results.title: Who Is the Bad Art Friend?
results.abstract: Art often draws inspiration from life — but what happens when it’s your life? Inside the curious case of Dawn Dorland v. Sonya Larson.

results.title: Ndakasi, Gorilla Who Photobombed a Selfie, Dies in the Arms of Her Caretaker
results.abstract: She died at age 14 in the Democratic Republic of Congo after “a prolonged illness,” said the park where she lived.
geo_facet: Virunga National Park (Congo, Democratic Republic of)

media.caption: Ndakasi with her caregiver, Andre Bauma, a few days before her death on Sept. 26 at Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

results.adx_keywords: Maps;Vikings;Middle Ages (Historical Period);Geography;Forgery;Research;Libraries and Librarians;Archaeology and Anthropology;Yale Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library;Yale University;Europe;Greenland
results.title: Yale Says Its Vinland Map, Once Called a Medieval Treasure, Is Fake
results.abstract: For decades, researchers at Yale and elsewhere have questioned the authenticity of a map that seemed to reflect Viking travels to North America. The school now says the case is closed.
org_facet: Yale Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

media.caption: The Vinland Map was unveiled in 1965 by a Yale team that believed it was made in 1440. A new team found a titanium compound used in inks first produced in the 1920s.

results.adx_keywords: Libel and Slander;Grammar;Social Media;Compensation for Damages (Law);internal-storyline-no;Gan, Stuart;Zadravic, Anthony;Facebook Inc;Australia
results.title: Missing Apostrophe in Facebook Post Lands a Man in Defamation Court
results.abstract: An Australian man claimed a real estate agent did not pay its “employees” retirement funds. The lack of a punctuation mark may cost him thousands.

results.title: Chicago’s mayor guts the city’s vaccine mandate for public workers.
results.abstract: A day after President Biden visited to issue a national plea for more vaccine mandates, Mayor Lori Lightfoot said Chicago’s public workers could opt out of the city’s until the end of the year by getting regularly tested.

media.caption: A view of Chicago last winter. Mayor Lori Lightfoot said on Friday that city employees could avoid the vaccine mandate she issued in August by getting tested twice a week through the end of the year.

results.adx_keywords: Bears;National Parks, Monuments and Seashores;Dehring, Samantha;Yellowstone National Park
results.title: Woman Jailed for Close Encounter With Grizzly and Cubs at Yellowstone
results.abstract: The woman was sentenced to four days in jail and was barred from the park for a year for not yielding space to the bear and three cubs.

media.caption: A grizzly bear with two cubs at Yellowstone National Park in 2015. The park has regulations that prohibit visitors from getting too close to large wildlife.
